Memoranda as to the basis (m
which the Baltimore Y. M. ('. A.
might co-operate with the Johns
Hopkins University in the erection
and administration of a social center on the Homewood campus
were tentatively adopted at a
joint meeting of committees, representing the -V" and the University Board of Trustees last Thursday. This proposed agreement
will be presented to the Directors
of the Baltimore Association and
to the Trustees of the University
for consideration at their respective May meetings. Pending authoritative action by the boards,
further details cannot now be announced.

SPRING ELECTIONS TO
BE HELD THURSDAY
Following the 0. 1). K,
public initiation at the last
assembly; President Hiss announced that nominations
were in order for next year's
Sindent Council president.
Six men were put up. Heyn,
President of the A. A. Board,
then opened the nominations
for delegates to that body.
According to the new A. A.
Board constitution, votes
must be cast for five seniors,
three juniors, two sopohomores, and one each of the
post graduate nominees. The
ballot for the elections will
also have a space in which
to vote for the most popular
senior.
Withdrawals and
elections will be held at the
assembly this week. The
polls will be held open until
1 P. M. in order that all
'nay vote.

EXCEL RED SKINS IN ATTACK AND DEFENSE

Homewood was transformed into a miniature battlefield last Friday when the Hopkins 11. 0. T. C.
unit underwent its annual inspection to determine whether it
should be placed on the "Distinguished College" list. The inspecting officers, Major Lawrence and
Major Danforth, seemed well
pleased with the condition of the
unit after examining it.

TWO NEW HOPKINS
RECORDS MADE
Two new Hopkins' records
were made in the track meet
with Maryland Saturday,
bringing the year's total to
three. Tom McNeal, erstwhile baseball pitcher, broke
the old javelin record, by five
feet, hurling the shaft 164
feet 4 inches. He was forced,
however, to take second to
Supplee in the event. His
throws have increased with
each succeeding meet.
Ralph HMS broke his-own
Hopkins record in the shotput with a heave of 46 feet
10Y, inches.
The other new Hopkins record made this year was
Gwinn's time of 4 minutes
and 27 3-5 seconds in the mile
run against Lafayette.

Hopkins racqueters won one
tennis match and' tied another
during the past week. On. Wednesday, the Jay netmen defeated
St. Johns by the score of 6 to 1
and on Thursday, Catholic University was held to a 3 to 3 tie
at Washington.
The victory over St. John's
marked Vthe second win scored over
the Cadets, the Hopkins team having defeated them earlier in the
season at Baltimore. The only
Hopkins mean to suffer ddeat
against St. John's was Wagner,
who was beaten by O'Neill by the
scores of 6-4, 8-10, 7-5.
Darkness halted the Catholic
University match, while Goldstein
and- Block of Hopkins were battling , Gardes and Riorden in the
doubles. Hopkins captured three
of the_ five singles matches and
the Washington netmen took the
first of the doubles.

Hopkins racqueters won one
tennis match and' tied another
during the past week. On. Wednesday, the Jay netmen defeated
St. Johns by the score of 6 to 1
and on Thursday, Catholic University was held to a 3 to 3 tie
at Washington.
The victory over St. John's
marked Vthe second win scored over
the Cadets, the Hopkins team having defeated them earlier in the
season at Baltimore. The only
Hopkins mean to suffer ddeat
against St. John's was Wagner,
who was beaten by O'Neill by the
scores of 6-4, 8-10, 7-5.
Darkness halted the Catholic
University match, while Goldstein
and- Block of Hopkins were battling , Gardes and Riorden in the
doubles. Hopkins captured three
of the_ five singles matches and
the Washington netmen took the
first of the doubles.
